Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.io

Class Parser

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.io.Parser
Direct Known Subclasses:
DefaultParser
public class Parser extends Object
A parser converts text into objects according to rules. A parser works in three stages. First, text is tokenized. Then the sequence of tokens is matched against patterns to produce a parse tree. Finally, the parse tree is given to a builder to create the object.

A grammar, or list of parsing rules, is defined in terms of two kinds of symbols: non-terminal symbols that represent complex things and terminal symbols that represent basic building blocks like keywords, names, numbers, and strings. A parsing rule has a left-hand side which must always be a single non-terminal symbol and a right-hand side which is a pattern, or a way to check whether a list of tokens is formatted correctly to represent an object. If there is more than one way to parse a non-terminal symbol, the pattern may be a selection, which is a list of patterns that will be tried in order.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors
    Constructor
    Description
    Parser()
    Constructs a new parser with a default tokenizer, no parsing rules, and only simple builders for for terminal symbols.

  • Method Details

    • getTokenizer

      public Tokenizer getTokenizer()
      Returns this parser's tokenizer.
      Returns:
      the tokenizer

    • setTokenizer

      public void setTokenizer(Tokenizer tokenizer)
      Sets this parser's tokenizer.
      Parameters:
      tokenizer - the new tokenizer to use

    • getRule

      public Pattern getRule(NonTerminal symbol)
      Returns the pattern the parser will try to match tokens against when parsing text as a given non-terminal symbol. If there are multiple ways to parse the non-terminal symbol, the pattern returned may be a selection.
      Parameters:
      symbol - the non-terminal symbol whose parsing rule is desired
      Returns:
      the pattern this parser uses to parse that non-terminal symbol

    • setRule

      public void setRule(NonTerminal symbol, Pattern pattern)
      Sets the pattern this parser will try to match tokens against when parsing text as the given non-terminal symbol.
      Parameters:
      symbol - the non-terminal symbol whose parsing rule is to be set
      pattern - the pattern this parser should use to parse the non-terminal symbol

    • addRule

      public void addRule(NonTerminal symbol, Pattern pattern)
      Adds an additional pattern to the end of the list of patterns that this parser will try to match tokens against when parsing text as the given non-terminal symbol. If the current pattern is a selection, the given pattern is added to the end of its list; otherwise, the pattern used for this non-terminal will be set to a selection of the current pattern and the given pattern.
      Parameters:
      symbol - the non-terminal symbol to which a parsing rule will be added
      pattern - an additional pattern this parser can use when trying to parse the non-terminal symbol

    • getBuilder

      public Builder getBuilder(Symbol symbol)
      Returns the builder that will be used to create objects from parse trees when parsing text as a given symbol.
      Parameters:
      symbol - the symbol whose associated builder is desired
      Returns:
      the builder used to create objects when parsing text as this symbol

    • setBuilder

      public Builder setBuilder(Symbol symbol, Builder builder)
      Sets the builder that will be used to create objects from parse trees when parsing text as a given symbol.
      Parameters:
      symbol - the symbol whose associated builder will be changed
      builder - the new builder to use when parsing text as that symbol
      Returns:
      the builder previously associated with the symbol, or null if no builder was previous associated with the symbol

    • parse

      public <T> T parse(Reader reader, Class<T> type) throws IOException, ParseException
      Reads all text from a reader and converts it to an object according to this parser's tokenizer, parsing rules, and builders.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of object to be parsed
      Parameters:
      reader - the source of text to be parsed
      type - the Java class of the object to be parsed
      Returns:
      the parsed object
      Throws:
      IOException - if an exception occurred while reading from the reader
      ParseException - if the text cannot be parsed as that kind of objects
      ClassCastException - if the object created cannot be cast to the given type

    • parse

      public <T> T parse(String string, Class<T> type) throws ParseException
      Parses a string of text and converts it to an object.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of object to be parsed
      Parameters:
      string - the string of text to be parsed
      type - the Java class of the object to be parsed
      Returns:
      the parsed object
      Throws:
      ParseException - if the text cannot be parsed as that kind of objects
      ClassCastException - if the object created cannot be cast to the given type

    • parse

      public <T> T parse(File file, Class<T> type) throws IOException, ParseException
      Parses a text File and converts it to an object. If the object bring parsed is a problem, the problem's name will be set to the file's name.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of object to be parsed
      Parameters:
      file - the text file to be parsed
      type - the Java class of the object to be parsed
      Returns:
      the parsed object
      Throws:
      IOException - if an exception occurred while reading from the file
      ParseException - if the text cannot be parsed as that kind of objects
      ClassCastException - if the object created cannot be cast to the given type
